The stories were good, but most movies did notfare too good.I call them science fiction gold...as every movie had a bit of good in there, could have been the clothes they wore, or the old cars they were using or wasit those visible wires to hold the space ships. reviewText: “Beyond the Time Barrier” is a science fiction film from 1960. Scheming time travellers, mutants on a rampage and a small band of survivors holding out in an underground city are some of the ingredients. So far, the concept sounds familiar!This time, a cosmic virus triggered by radioactive dust in the atmosphere, rather than an actual World War III, is what destroys most of humanity. A USAF test pilot from pre-apocalypse days somehow ends up in the mutant-ridden future, and must travel back to 1960 to warn the world's leaders about the impending disaster. The bad guys all seem Russian or German…While the concept isn't all that bad, the execution is low-budget, and “Beyond the Time Barrier” never really takes off. Not an outright turkey, but not a really god film either. Only two stars.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In 1960 Major William Allison (Robert Clarke) flies an experimental rocket plane "X-80" (looks suspiciously like a Convair F-102 interceptor) in just the right conditions to break the Time Barrier.He lands in an abandoned airfield and is disoriented. He stumbles around looking like someone trying to find a place to relieve himself. Soon he discovers a world unlike anything he just left.I will not go through all the details as that is why you are going to watch the movie. However I can tell you that women in the future still have that 60's flare for future fashions.  And talk ablaut a 60's fantasy most of the women including Princess Trirene (Darlene Tompkins) do not talk. Turns out Major Allison has to find out who the good guys are and who the bad guys are. In the end he may prove to be of value to us in preventing a future catastrophe.Any way you watch this film it is a good old sci-fi story that tries to explain time travel.

reviewText: Filmed concurrently with The Amazing Transparent Man, Beyond the Time Barrier is a decent little time travel film that has largely been forgotten since its release in 1960.  Director Edgar G. Ulmer was able to shoot most of the film in the Texas Centennial Exhibition Fair Park buildings and a nearby military airfield, wrapping up the entire shoot in a mere 10 days.  Robert Clarke produced as well as starred in the movie as an Air Force test pilot who accidentally journeys 64 years into the future to find a largely desolate world where the remnants of mankind have divided into two enemy factions, with the more advanced, underground city-dwellers on perpetual guard against the dangerous mutants who still live topside.  Yes, the plot does sound a little bit like a well-known H.G. Wells story, and that's precisely why this film, shot in late 1959, was not released until July 1960, mere weeks before the much-anticipated The Time Machine hit theatres (there's nothing like borrowing the publicity that someone else is already paying for).  Like many science fiction films of the 1950s, Beyond the Time Barrier does have a bit of an anti-nuke agenda, but I must say it presents this message in a slightly different and rather effective manner.The film opens with Major William Allison (Robert Clarke) taking the super-nifty new X-80 aircraft on what is essentially a sub-orbital spin, unleashing the full power of the specially-designed rocket engine at the unprecedented height of 500,000 feet.  During the test, he loses contact with mission control and gets hit with a cheesy special effect, but he still manages to return to base successfully.  Upon arrival, though, he is beyond perplexed to find what should be a bustling Air Force base totally abandoned and in an advanced state of decay.  He is eventually captured and taken to a mysterious underground citadel housing a society that has never heard of the United States Air Force.  That is because the year is 2024, and a terrible epidemic caused by cosmic rays almost wiped out civilization beginning in 1971.  All but a handful of the residents are deaf and mute, which doesn't help Allison's search for answers as to how he got there.The obvious question is, of course, whether or not Allison can find a way to return to his own time - or if he will even want to, since the easier choice is to just stay there with the future's hottest babe and do his best to keep the largely sterile population from dying out.  The cast list is sort of interesting.  Vladimir Sokoloff plays The Supreme Leader of the Citadel, while the lovely Darlene Tompkins continually steals the show as his mind-reading deaf-mute granddaughter.  The Captain is played (badly) by former Washington Redskin and stunt man Boyd Morgan, and the director's very own daughter Arianne Ulmer (credited as Arianne Arden) plays a scientist.My favorite part of the film is the scientific mumbo-jumbo that is used to help explain how Allison somehow broke through the time barrier flying at only a fraction of the speed of light, with the proposed method of his returning to his own time coming in at a close second.  How can you not love the low-budget science fiction flicks of the late 1950s?  The film's saving grace, though, is the ending.  The science of it may not make a lot of sense, but it's not the same old boring ending you'll find in other movies of this type.  The film really needed that good ending because the majority of the script is pretty weak.  I've heard that there were a lot of script-related issues at play here, some of which weren't resolved by the time filming began.  I must say I find that quite easy to believe.  Still, though, Beyond the Time Barrier seems to carry an air of sincerity throughout, and that helps make up for some of its plot-related problems.
summary: A largely forgotten but decent little low-budget time-travel film from 1960
Title: N/A

reviewText: Edgar G. Ulmer's "Beyond the Time Barrier" is still one of the best little science fiction films ever made and is as relevent today as it was when it first came out. Filmed in black and white, the film makes creative use of simple geometric shapes to depict a not-too-distant apocalyptic future. Our test pilot hero Robert Clarke leaves his base one morning and an hour later returns to the same base, except he finds himself in the future. He falls in love with pretty Darlene Tompkins, is menaced by sly villainess Aranne Arden (Ulmer's real life daughter) and is tutored by wise Vladimir Solokoff who, as a veteran actor, adds cred to proceedings. "Beyond the Time Barrier" questions the rate of human progress and how we use technology. One day it would be great to see all Ulmer's films released on DVD with commentaries and interviews. "Beyond the Time Barrier" in particular deserves this treatment.
Title: N/A

reviewText: BEYOND THE TIME BARRIER was made because some buildings in a Texas State Fair were available and looked futuristic enough to use in a film.  That statement alone guarantees a low budget.  Despite that, the film is fun--a good performance from Robert Clark holds it all together and, in the 60's, it looked really good.The disk itself is of indifferent quality.  Dark, scratchy in places, it would be nice to see a restored version but, for now and at the low price this disk commands, it's a nice item to pick up for a casual watch.
summary: Nice programmer with some good ideas
Title: N/A

reviewText: This must be among the last things the veteran character actor, Vladimir Sokoloff, did before his death in 1962. His  will be a familiar face, if not name, to anyone who watches the movies of the thirty years previous  to that. This movie achieves about what was expected given the budget allocated which, I imagine,  was about $750.00, depending on what  the Actor's Equity minimum wage was at that time. Certainly nothing was spent on scenery or a script, no doubt resorting to the bottom drawer of rejects for the latter.There was another familiar and able face, see if you recognize it behind the beard, but it appears to me he made the appearance to help out the Director who must have been a buddy. Criticism, however, is not warranted, much like beating the proverbial dead horse. Clearly, this was intended as a time-killer for the 3AM Movie of the  Night on the one TV channel beamed to an isolated island off the Maine Coast, where 10 people lived around a lighthouse,  which still used fish oil to light their beacon.If you really must see it, and are going to pay, be sure to get it in one of the collections selling for less than this one film is.
summary: On a par with a  poor Monogram Film release

reviewText: One thing I like about those old 50's movies: they don't waste time and get right into action.  The special effects are fairly good and I liked the way they used a real plane for the X-80 while on the ground and a cleverly modified model for the shots in space.  I was totally hooked to my screen up to the point where the pilot is taken prisoner.  It seems the male of the future not only became impotent but also dumb.  The script is rather poor from this point on in the film and the set always look the same no matter where they go.  But nevertheless i still think this film is a good entertainment.

reviewText: I enjoy watching a good "bad" sci-fi movie every now and then, and the story of this one caught my eye. An air force pilot goes on a test flight which sends him into space. In his ascent, his plane briefly goes off the planned path and when he returns to earth for his landing, he arrives 64 years in the future.This film was done in 1960 before man landed on the moon, so the scientific basis for the story is completely based on hypothesis, and while we know its basis to be wrong, it is fascinating that they were able to explain it so reasonably. In the film's future, men have had to burrow below ground. Nuclear testing has depleted the ozone layer so tremendously that it is no longer safe to live above ground. Those who do are now mutants. The rest of the population is becoming sterile and deaf/mute. It is up to the pilot to reverse his flight path and go back to his present to prevent this horrible future from happening.While this film could have been stellar, it relies too heavily on what by 1960 had become sci-fi stereotypes. The political system has reverted to emperors and princesses, the victims of the earth's condition are represented as bloodthirsty monsters, like many alien races were depicted, and the cities are cold and metallic looking. It is incredibly predictable and dull with none of the actors offering more to their roles than a body to fulfill an established type.
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Scotman's Film & Book Reviews "Film & Book Re...
reviewText: First Impressions & the DVD:  Beyond the Time Barrier was on point as a fairly substandard film put together by Alpha Video, a company in my experience which does little to clean up an original film and just slaps it on a DVD.When you open the DVD it shows a drop down list for the logo, a trailer and the film itself.  Pretty cheaply put together.And the quality of the film is fairly bad, a high contrast black & white print.  I've seen much better quality black & white films from this era 1960.Story and Plot:The acting was pretty routine and the story, though it had some interesting points to make here and there, was fairly cardboard and uninteresting.A man takes a flight to near space and accidentally goes into a time warp, ending up on Earth 67 years later, in the year 2024.  It takes the guy forever to figure out that he is in the future despite all evidence.  He's even asked point blank "Do you know what year this is?" and he says "What does that have to do with it, of course I do!"Despite the slow thinking jet pilot, there are some bright spots in this story.  We have the mutants and the sterilized humans, many of them deaf mutes, brought on by a plague that hit the Earth in the 1970s and wiped out half the population, with many escaping to colonies on Mars and Venus.I thought the whole "plague from outer space" thing and the fact that numerous atom bomb tests destroyed the layer protecting us from "cosmic rays" was a bit far-fetched.  On the other hand we do have the current ozone layer problem, so maybe not!Darlene Tompkins plays the deaf mute girl, the few who are fertile, and she wants to make it with the astronaut, played clumsily by Robert Clarke.  The cardboard acting on his part just ruined it for me.  Darlene has no lines (!) and does a great job of bobbing her head up and down, LOL.There's a whole betrayal theme at the end of the movie that's worth watching, as well as the fight with the mutants.  The director seems set on padding his time with people walking from one area to another slowly as we watch others marching around.  Not sure who they are!Bottom Line:  A time waster and not really much of a time travel story, made worse by the film quality.  A film with a similar theme (astronauts going through a time barrier and end up in Earth's future) such as Planet of the Apes is much more worthwhile.
summary: Poor production & transfer for a decent sci fi tale!

reviewText: A film that suffers from a much-used premise shackled to a miniscule budget, the latter item the responsibility of the producer and star, Robert Clarke.  Spartan does not begin to describe the 'sets', although the principal actors do their best with some pretty sketchy material, burdened with too much expositional dialog. Still, fun to watch and fairly well-paced once the obligatory background explanations have been dutifully delivered. Pretty decent diversion on a rainy afternoon.

reviewText: In my opinion, "Beyond the Time Barrier" is one of those old science fiction movies with a reputation that exceeds its reality. I commend Sinister Cinema for offering a DVD release of this minor, obscure 1960 black-and-white film. But I would stop far short of calling it a "classic," and I certainly don't put it on a par with the true classics of that year--for instance, "The Time Machine," to mention just one.There's nothing wrong with "Beyond the Time Barrier," really. It has a decent (if simple) plot, a few relatively interesting characters, pretty good production values (although it's a bit dark and contrasty), a low-key, non-intrusive music score and, best of all, reasonable technical accuracy in parts. While the idea of an experimental rocket plane exceeding the speed of light and jumping through the "time barrier" is, of course, absurd, the details of the aircraft and its mission early on are pretty good. There are shots of a real Convair F-102 "Delta Dagger" that the Air Force apparently made available for the film. I'll overlook the few times when a Convair F-106 "Delta Dart" stands in for the F-102--who but a techno-geek would notice? The model aircraft shown "in space" matches the real one (there's no stock V-2 footage here!). I was impressed when the pre-mission briefing talked about the aircraft extending "ventral fins" and the model in space then did exactly that. Also, the matte paintings of the city remind me of scenes in "Forbidden Planet," which is high praise.But the rest of "Beyond the Time Barrier" does not live up to these positive elements. It's pretty shallow, doesn't build any suspense or real interest, and I do not like the plot point of having all but a couple of the inhabitants of the future city being deaf and mute. Why? I can almost imagine it as simply a way to avoid paying the actors and actresses more for speaking roles...There's no real menu screen, just a simple list with "Logo," "Trailer" and "Play Movie," of the type any amateur can make using a DVD-authoring program. It's so basic that it doesn't even have, for example, a screencap from the movie as a background. As I said, simple. There are no chapter stops, of course, not that they're really necessary for a 91-minute movie. No extras, either, naturally.The title of my review sums up my overall reaction to this movie. Never having seen it before, I enjoyed it well enough on my first watching. But it's probably not a film I'd ever want to watch again, so it goes into my public library donation box. Rather than taking up space on my media shelf with it, I'll check it out if the urge ever strikes me again in the future to venture "Beyond the Time Barrier."
summary: Worth Seeing Once, but Not a Keeper

reviewText: While this is no lost masterpiece, and objectively speaking deserves 3 & 1/2 stars at best, I'm rounding that up to 4 stars. Why? Because for all its cheapness, this film made an impact on me when I was a boy, particularly with its far-from-typical ending. And watching it again now, I can better appreciate how the filmmakers did they best they could with the little they had, and cooked up a story that lingered with me over the decades for good reasons.The plot is simple: an Air Force pilot manages to accidentally break the time barrier, returning to his air field to find it deserted & overgrown. While he's slow to catch on to what's happened, the emptiness & desolation of a world he remembers well & took for granted is depicted with a certain crude intensity. Even as a small boy, I felt the scariness of finding the familiar world reduced to ruins & fading memories; that holds true even now, from an adult's viewpoint.Soon the truth is revealed: a plague has wiped out most of mankind, leaving most of the survivors as infertile mutants. A small underground redoubt holds the last remnants of civilization & science, already psychologically reduced to a cultish mentality, with the telepathic deaf-mute daughter of their leader one of the few fertile women left alive. Naturally our hero is expected to mate with her & restore the human race ... but not only are the mutants forever threatening this last haven of the human race, but some of those who escaped to Mars & Venus have their own treacherous plans as well.For all the padding, slowness, and wooden dialogue that abounds, a genuine sense of impending doom & despair really soaks every frame. Again, even as a boy, I knew before the film ended that it couldn't end well, or at least that a happy ending would ruin everything that came before. And the filmmakers didn't let me down. While offering a sliver of hope for humanity, the ending remains a tragedy for our protagonist & the doomed, innocent Eve of the future.So, it's flawed to be sure. But it has real ideas, and for that reason stands up well against many of the story-free CGI-fests of the present day. Watch it with an open mind, and you may discover something worthwhile & haunting -- recommended!
summary: Low-budget science-fiction with some haunting qualities
